pros: As a second career professional, I have found that working at IBM has truly fulfilled my desire and goal to find the meaningful capstone of my professional journey. IBM is a company that encourages and fosters the growth and innovation of all in a very inclusive environment. From the support of management, to the highly collaborative and innovative culture, to the expansive array of learning paths, certification tracks, and learning resources, IBM provides the means for all to not only succeed in their current position, but to fully prepare themselves for success at the next level, and in reaching their full potential. I have found the work to be extraordinarily meaningful and fulfilling, such that I'm happy to go to work everyday, and proud to be an IBMer!
cons: IBM is such a large global company that getting oriented can seem rather daunting and overwhelming. But with support of the management team and peers, and with some individual effort to network and learn, that downside is effectively eliminated.

review_title: Hard to climb, railroaded into roles when at certain locations
pros:
- Laid back work environment
- Genuinely really nice people to work with
- Fun office environments
- Good work life balance
- Good diversity, as a PoC
cons:
I was railroaded into a certain role that was not Software Developer oriented. This is pretty much just terrible management overall, and ultimately caused me to leave when I couldn't be moved back into development.

Pay is quite low for a company of this reputation and size. Most companies start upwards of 40k+, but IBM starts grads at 30k.

Some projects are too big and too old, and the technological debt is high.

No bonuses.

There's no structure for getting promotions. Generally, moving up a band is subjective, so your manager can keep you at the same level for a long time, for no reason, if you're unlucky.

review_title: IBM is one of the world's three best employers
job_title: Executive IT Specialist in Jacksonville, FL
pros: It has definitely been a very different year at IBM, now in my 20th, but IBM did everything imaginable, and more, to help our customers this year, and to ensure the health and well being of its employees! Shifting to basically a full time at home team, there were many challenges socially, personally, and with virtual working. IBM made sure we had the tools to help with all of these. We continued to excel assisting our customers adjust to this year and the "new normal." IBM put its employees first, in ensuring our health and well being. And on top of it, made sure we continued to learn! IBM is the place to choose if you love learning, and why IBM is one of the world’s three best employers. I spent over 200 hours on education this year, which turned out to be quite the busy year!
cons: Of course, we are in a big period of adjustment, with the leadership changes and new concentrations. So you must be flexible.

job_title: Job Seeker in Culver City, CA
pros:
Best part of my time at IBM was my colleagues from countries around the world. Technical, knowledgeable, super sharp, client focused, team oriented. It was a pleasure working with them. 

Also the company treated me like a professional. I worked remotely for the last 19 years of my career and never felt micromanaged. I was trusted to get my work done regardless of how I allocated my time to it during the day. I was judged based on my output, not my facetime.

Benefits are very employee-friendly and progressive. Company walks the talk of supporting diversity.
cons:
Compensation is below average. Raises are rare. My salary increases over the last 10 years of my career averaged less than 1% a year. 

Layoffs, excuse me, "resource rebalancing" happen regularly, as often as twice a year. The company invests more in stock buybacks and other financial engineering to appease investors at the expense of the employees and the core business. Amazon has blitzed past IBM in the cloud space because IBM tried to pivot to cloud on the cheap. Now IBM is a 2nd tier cloud company trying desperately to play catch-up.

review_title: A company dedicated to keeping your skills current and relevant.
pros: IBM builds education and training into your daily job. This means they not only encourage you to stay current, but they back it up by giving you real work hours to complete training. Education is provided via numerous weekly webinars given by Subject Matter Experts across an expansive list of subjects (e.g., Quantum computing to Growing Your Career). Education also is available an endless catalog of up-to-date online curriculum, classes, and funded attendance at IBM and non-IBM Conferences, as well funded classes/curriculum from outside IBM. These classes lead to certifications (also funded) and badges. I've even attended classes at Harvard. IBM is truly the place to grow your skills and your career.
cons: IBM is pivoting its solutions to support a hybrid multi-cloud strategy. This is good, but at times the transition brings frustrations.

pros:
At engineer / developer level, generally a good company to work for. Interesting set of technologies. The local management / leads in Dublin are sheltering for the more general BS at wider company level.
Good work/life balance, ability to work for home.
cons:
This is a company driven by non-technical exec at the top, and a chain of non-technical managers, which is resulting in a very low technical level compared to competition in the Cloud space. Very different from the likes of Google, Amazon, etc.
The vast majority of senior technical leads (STSMs / DEs) are relatively weak - do not exhibit any real leadership, do not have any specific expertise/technical talent, do not understand what is going on at lower level, and have mastered the exercise of BS / politics to seduce their non-technical exec masters. 
Genuine technical talents typically leave the company before they reach senior level with rare exceptions.
Bunch of clowns running a Cloud like it is an on-prem software from the 90s.

pros:
- Puts a premium on integrity above everything.
- Follows a pay for performance philosophy.
- Encourages and fosters continuous development of its talents.
cons:
- Several managers are ill-equipped to adequately support and motivate their teams. There are those who have no genuine connection with their direct reports, lacking capability to build rapport and sense of belongingness among team members.
- Some leaders are out of touch on what's happening on the ground. At times, strategies don't make sense (example: compelling a broad range of sectors/service lines to be cross-certified in technologies that are irrelevant to the experience and skill sets of the impacted practices).
- Not all centers are created equal: no matter how willing you are to work across borders, there are geos that simply don't work well when put together, especially in high-pressure engagements.

review_title: No raises, no bonuses, and will work you to death and still ask for more
pros: If you enjoy not having any sort of personal life, than being an IBM service technician is for you. My normal hours are Monday thru Friday 8-5 and on call one week and weekend a month. In the evening and on the weekends, you’ll have the opportunity to be harassed by customers, dispatchers and management trying to get you to leave your home and family to go service a machine. They sell 24/7 coverage but yet have nobody working past 5pm. They rely on us monitoring our phones when we are off the clock. It’s a great system and a great company to work for..... so much so, that I am willing to take a cut in pay and benefits in order to get the heck away from IBM. 9 years with them and it gets worse every day.
cons: No personal or family life... at all. Every plan you make will be ruined. Not enough staff to cover evenings or nights anymore so your subject to working any old time they call u. You have to literally request off your weekends if you want to do anything and even then you will be pressured and harassed to work because of the number of customers wanting service on the weekend and not enough people to do the work. Our new CSP system has created a ton of barriers to even do the job. Folks all over the world are ordering parts for us and are sending them all over the place and then we are on the hook to track them down. If you want pertinent info for the ticket, you have to drill down into several different menus... it’s terrible and has made an already tortured life at IBM that much worse. I wouldn’t tell my worst enemy to come work here it’s so bad. Everyone on my team hates this job with a passion and most retired the moment they could. The ones left can’t keep up anymore and working 30 hours overtime every week is getting old. Oh yeah, health insurance has gone up so much since Obamacare came out years ago, that I’m now on the “emergency” plan with hsa because it would be almost 500 a month for me and 2 kids on the good plan I used to be on. Dental is 130 a month for me and 2 kids. We used to get a small bonus every year of a thousand or less (before taxes) and they managed to take that away from us to. Being a technician for IBM is the bottom of the barrel. We are the red headed step children that IBM doesn’t give 2 craps about yet we are the ones who actually see the clients face to face. Guess what, I have nothing good to say about IBM to clients when I’m around them. Sorry for the rant, but I just worked all day Saturday and then had a code upgrade project that ran all night into Sunday and didn’t get home until 6am. Funny thing is, that’s normal for us these days and it shouldn’t be. There is NO limit to how much they will make you work.
